title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: training and selection
detailed_description: This comprehensive study describes the preparation, execution, and outcomes of biomedical research using male C57BL/6N mice aboard the 30-day Bion-M 1 biosatellite, Russia's first such mission after a 16-year hiatus. The experiment aimed to elucidate cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems (muscle, bone, cardiovascular, nervous, sensorimotor, and immune) to long-term microgravity exposure. The project combined in vivo measurements (continuous telemetry for blood pressure monitoring, behavioral analyses for locomotion, cognition, and vestibular function) with extensive in vitro studies of tissues using biochemical and molecular techniques. Rigorous pre-flight training included co-adaptation in housing groups and adaptation to specialized paste food diet designed to minimize aggression among mature male mice. The training program involved environmental enrichment and daily handling. After flight, surviving mice (36% survival rate due to habitat mechanical issues rather than aggression) exhibited pronounced disadaptation to Earth's gravity including reduced motor activity, exophthalmia, and altered urination patterns. The mission provided invaluable data for over 70 collaborative studies and established operational protocols for future international rodent research in space, demonstrating that male mice can be successfully employed in space biomedical research when appropriate training protocols are implemented.
platform: Bion-M 1 biosatellite

title: Microgravity Induces Pelvic Bone Loss through Osteoclastic Activity, Osteocytic Osteolysis, and Osteoblastic Cell Cycle Inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
detailed_description: This research investigates the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying rapid bone loss in mature female C57BL/6J mice subjected to 15 days of microgravity on the STS-131 space shuttle mission. The study challenges the traditional view that bone loss in space is solely due to increased osteoclast activity by examining osteocytic osteolysis and cell cycle arrest. Using microCT and high-resolution nanoCT analysis, the study revealed 6.29% decrease in bone volume fraction and 11.91% reduction in bone thickness in the pelvic region. TRAP staining showed a dramatic 170% increase in osteoclast-covered bone surfaces. Importantly, nanoCT revealed signs of osteocytic osteolysis including 17% increase in lacunar cross-sectional area, 14% increase in perimeter, and 6% increase in canalicular diameter. Gene expression analysis found significant upregulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMP1, MMP3, MMP10) with MMP10 specifically localized to osteocytes. The cell cycle inhibitor CDKN1a/p21 was upregulated 3.31-fold and localized to osteoblasts, suggesting cell cycle arrest rather than apoptosis. The apoptosis inducer Trp53 was downregulated, consistent with survival-promoting rather than cell death pathways. This study provides new evidence for multiple mechanisms of spaceflight-induced bone loss beyond traditional osteoclastic resorption.
platform: STS-131 Space Shuttle Discovery

title: Stem Cell Health and Tissue Regeneration in Microgravity
detailed_description: This comprehensive review examines the effects of microgravity on stem cell function and tissue regenerative capacity, with implications for long-duration spaceflight and regenerative medicine applications. The study synthesizes current knowledge about how microgravity affects various stem cell populations including mesenchymal stem cells, hematopoietic stem cells, and tissue-specific progenitors. Key findings indicate that microgravity can both enhance and impair stem cell functions depending on the cell type and experimental conditions. The review discusses mechanisms including altered mechanotransduction, changes in cell cycle regulation, modified differentiation pathways, and altered response to growth factors. Microgravity culture systems have shown promise for expanding certain stem cell populations while maintaining pluripotency. The research has significant implications for developing countermeasures to maintain tissue health during long-duration spaceflight and for advancing ground-based regenerative medicine through microgravity simulation technologies. The study emphasizes the need for standardized protocols and the development of appropriate ground-based analogs for space research.
organism: Various stem cell types (human and animal models)
platform: Multiple platforms including ISS, ground-based microgravity simulators

title: Microgravity Reduces the Differentiation and Regenerative Potential of Embryonic Stem Cells
detailed_description: This study investigates how microgravity affects embryonic stem cell differentiation and regenerative capacity using both actual spaceflight and ground-based microgravity simulation. The research employed multiple experimental approaches including rotating wall vessel bioreactors, random positioning machines, and actual spaceflight experiments to examine embryonic stem cell behavior under reduced gravity conditions. Results demonstrated that microgravity exposure significantly altered stem cell differentiation patterns, reducing their ability to form specific cell lineages while potentially maintaining pluripotency markers. The study found changes in gene expression patterns related to cell cycle control, apoptosis resistance, and differentiation signaling pathways. Proteomic analysis revealed altered protein expression profiles affecting cellular metabolism and stress response mechanisms. The research has important implications for understanding how space environments might affect human reproductive health and embryonic development during long-duration missions. Additionally, the findings contribute to the development of microgravity-based culture systems for stem cell expansion and tissue engineering applications on Earth.
platform: Ground-based microgravity simulators and spaceflight experiments

title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex quantitative real time PCR analysis of gene expression on the International Space Station
detailed_description: This groundbreaking study describes the development and validation of WetLab-2, a novel molecular biology laboratory system specifically designed for microgravity operations aboard the International Space Station. The system enables end-to-end RNA isolation and real-time gene expression analysis on-orbit, representing a significant advancement in space-based scientific capabilities. WetLab-2 includes a fluidic RNA Sample Preparation Module, fluid transfer devices, lyophilized PCR assays, centrifuge, and real-time PCR thermal cycler. During ISS increment 47/SPX-8, the system successfully demonstrated qPCR efficiency using DNA calibration standards that were comparable to Earth controls. The study achieved on-orbit multiplex gene expression analysis from Escherichia coli bacterial cells and mouse liver tissue RNA samples in approximately 3 hours, with data transmitted within 2 hours of completion. A key challenge identified was gas bubble formation during thermal cycling in microgravity, which increased noise and variability in results. This was successfully mitigated in a follow-up experiment using standard caps to pressurize PCR tubes. The validation of WetLab-2 establishes a new operational paradigm for complex molecular biology experiments in space and provides essential capabilities for future long-duration missions requiring on-orbit diagnostics and research capabilities.
organism: Escherichia coli and mouse liver tissue
platform: International Space Station (ISS)

title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
detailed_description: This research investigates the molecular effects of 15-day spaceflight on cardiac tissue gene expression in female C57BL/6J mice from the STS-131 space shuttle mission. The study hypothesized that spaceflight alters expression of genes related to oxidative stress and cell cycle regulation, potentially contributing to cardiovascular deconditioning. Using quantitative PCR arrays, researchers analyzed expression of 168 genes related to oxidative stress pathways and Trp53 signaling in cardiac tissue harvested approximately 3 hours post-landing. Results showed that 37 genes were significantly altered by spaceflight. Key findings included downregulation of the master antioxidant transcription factor Nfe2l2 (Nrf2), upregulation of NADPH oxidase 1 (Nox1) by 6.6-fold, and downregulation of prostaglandin-endoperoxide synthase 2 (Ptgs2), suggesting increased oxidative stress. The cell cycle inhibitor Cdkn1a (p21) was dramatically upregulated 6.8-fold and localized to osteoblasts, while the oncogene Myc was upregulated 3.9-fold. Inflammatory response genes including Tnf were significantly downregulated. Computational analysis revealed interconnected gene networks linking oxidative stress and cell cycle pathways, with potential associations to cardiovascular diseases. The study provides novel insights into molecular mechanisms of spaceflight-induced cardiac changes and identifies potential targets for countermeasure development.
platform: STS-131 Space Shuttle Discovery

title: Dose- and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-Like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
detailed_description: This comprehensive study examines the effects of space-like radiation on skeletal health using male C57BL6/J mice exposed to different types and doses of ionizing radiation at NASA's Space Radiation Laboratory. The research investigated both low linear-energy-transfer (LET) protons (150 MeV/n) and high-LET iron-56 ions (600 MeV/n) at doses ranging from 5-200 cGy, with endpoints at 5 weeks and 1 year post-irradiation. The study aimed to determine dose- and ion-dependent effects on bone structure and osteoblast function. Key findings revealed that high doses (200 cGy) of either protons or iron ions caused persistent cancellous bone loss, while only high-LET iron significantly inhibited osteoblastogenesis by over 90% and increased expression of oxidative stress genes including Catalase and Gadd45. Lower doses (<50 cGy) showed minimal effects on any measured parameter. In vitro experiments demonstrated that exogenous superoxide dismutase (SOD) protected osteoprogenitors from low-LET gamma radiation damage but provided limited protection against high-LET iron exposure, suggesting different damage mechanisms. The research provides crucial dose-response data for space radiation risk assessment and identifies oxidative stress as a key mechanism in radiation-induced bone damage, with implications for developing radioprotective countermeasures for long-duration space missions.
platform: NASA Space Radiation Laboratory (NSRL) - ground-based space radiation simulation

title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions
detailed_description: This comprehensive review and advocacy paper outlines NASA's approach to translational research in life sciences, emphasizing the critical need for coordinated efforts to develop medical countermeasures for human space exploration missions. The paper defines translational research at NASA as a two-phased effort: basic-to-applied translation (fundamental discoveries to countermeasure development) and applied-to-operational translation (countermeasure implementation in medical operations). The authors provide detailed examples of successful translational research in four key areas: immune response dysfunction, microbe-host interactions, oxidative stress responses, and visual impairment/intracranial pressure syndrome. The paper highlights specific research achievements including the demonstration that Salmonella typhimurium increases virulence in spaceflight conditions, identification of radiation-induced oxidative stress mechanisms in bone, and characterization of spaceflight-induced immune system alterations. The work emphasizes the importance of horizontal integration (multidisciplinary approaches) and vertical translation (interactions across the research continuum) to accelerate countermeasure development. The paper concludes with recommendations for enhanced partnerships, open science initiatives, and educational programs to advance NASA's translational research goals for enabling safe human exploration of Mars and beyond.
organism: Multiple organisms (humans, mice, Drosophila, Salmonella, cell cultures)
platform: Multiple platforms (ISS, Space Shuttle, Bion missions, ground-based analogs)

The study examined chemical analysis and other measurements made on lunar-treated plant seedlings grown for 14 to 21 days demonstrating direct interaction between germfree plants and lunar material.
methods: Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy, Flame Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy, Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy, Hydride Generation Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy
location: Apollo 15 and Apollo 16 missions, lunar surface and Earth surface controls

units.Aluminum: micrograms of element per gram dry weight
units.Boron: micrograms of element per gram dry weight
units.Calcium: micrograms of element per gram dry weight
units.Iron: micrograms of element per gram dry weight
units.Potassium: micrograms of element per gram dry weight

platform: Apollo Program - post-flight analysis

title: PH-04 Chile Peppers in Space
description: Growing plants in spaceflight presents challenges to achieve optimal plant growth and productivity. One of NASA's goals is growing edible crops in spaceflight to supplement the astronauts' diet with fresh vegetables and assess food safety of the crops. The Advanced Plant Habitat (APH), an enclosed, controlled plant growth facility on the ISS was used to grow chile peppers, Capsicum annum c.v. NuMex Espanola Improved. This was one of the longest continuous plant growth experiments conducted on ISS (137 days), producing 26 pepper fruit.
methods: 16S Amplicon Sequencing using Illumina MiSeq platform, paired-end 250bp reads
location: International Space Station - Japanese Experiment Module, Advanced Plant Habitat

units.Light Intensity: micromole per square meter per second

platform: International Space Station (ISS)

title: Analysis of Vegetable Seedlings Grown in Contact with Apollo 14 Lunar Surface Fines
description: Chemical analysis and other measurements made on lunar-treated plant seedlings grown for 14 to 21 days demonstrate a direct interaction between germfree plants and lunar material. Treated plants dissolved some lunar minerals and concentrated others in their tissues.
methods: Spectrochemical Analysis, Germination and Growth Assessment
authors: Research team members - details in dataset
platform: Apollo Program

title: Effects of 5-Ion Beam Irradiation and Hindlimb Unloading on Metabolic Pathways in Plasma and Brain of Behaviorally Tested WAG/Rij Rats - Plasma data
description: A limitation of simulated space radiation studies is that radiation exposure is not the only environmental challenge astronauts face during missions. Therefore, this study characterized behavioral and cognitive responses in a rat model exposed to both space radiation simulation and mechanical unloading to simulate microgravity effects.

units.Metabolites: concentration units as specified in dataset

platform: Ground-based space simulation

title: Life long effects of radiation and high fat diet on the mouse right ventricular tissue
description: Study of the long-term effects of single whole-body gamma and simulated GCR irradiation (IR) and consumption of a Western Diet (WD) on the heart's right ventricle (RV). Three-month-old C57Bl/6J wild-type mice were used to investigate cardiovascular impacts of space radiation exposure.
platform: Ground-based space radiation simulation

title: Investigating the Structure of Paramagnetic Aggregates from Colloidal Emulsions - 4 (InSPACE-4)
description: The overall objective of the InSPACE-4 investigation was to study the effects of particle shape and toggle duty cycle on the phase separation kinetics of particles in toggled fields. This ISS investigation was conducted using magnetic prolate ellipsoids with aspect ratios ranging from 2:1 to 4:1. The sample material consisted of randomly oriented nano Fe3O4 coated polymer beads within a fluid filled vial, creating a magnetorheological fluid (MR).
methods: Magnetic field manipulation, Birefringence measurements using crossed polarizers, Video microscopy, Particle tracking
location: International Space Station (ISS) - Microgravity Science Glovebox (MSG)
platform: International Space Station (ISS)

title: Coupled Growth in Hypermonotectics (CGH)
description: The overall objective of the Coupled Growth in Hypermonotectics is to understand the fundamental physics controlling solidification in immiscible alloy systems. The investigation flew aboard the Life and Microgravity Spacelab (LMS) mission during the summer of 1996. Processing conditions were controlled to force the production of an aligned fibrous phase in the microstructure of processed samples.
methods: Directional solidification using Advanced Gradient Heating Facility (AGHF), Metallographic analysis, Thermal gradient control
location: Space Shuttle - Life and Microgravity Spacelab (LMS) mission
platform: Space Shuttle

title: Unified Support for THERMOLAB - ISS, ICOPROSOL and PARSEC (EML USTIP Batch 2)
description: Investigation of anomalous nucleation events in zirconium samples during ISS-EML experiments. The anomalous nucleation events of interest are hypothesized to be caused by cavitation in the melt. Experiments replicated the conditions in which the nucleation events were previously observed.
methods: Electromagnetic levitation (EML), Containerless processing, Thermal analysis
location: International Space Station (ISS) - Materials Science Research Rack
platform: International Space Station (ISS)

title: Advanced Colloids Experiment -Temperature controlled- 2 (ACE-T2)
description: The objective of this experiment is the investigation of the assembly of complex structures from micron-scale colloidal particles interacting via tunable attractive interactions. Regulating temperature allows control of the strength of attractive interactions between particles.
methods: Light Microscopy Module (LMM), Fluids Integrated Rack (FIR), Temperature control, Video imaging at 30 fps
platform: International Space Station (ISS)

title: NASA Biological Institutional Scientific Collection (NBISC)
description: The NBISC is a biorepository of non-human biospecimens collected from NASA-funded spaceflight investigations and correlated ground studies. It receives, stores, documents, preserves, and makes these samples available to the scientific community. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
collections: Space Radiation / Human Research Program Biospecimen & Tissue Sharing Collection (BTSC)
sample_types: Tissue (various organs: muscle, bone, brain, liver, kidney, etc.)
methods: Samples are collected from NASA spaceflight and ground experiments, preserved, cataloged, and archived. Specimens not fully used in primary studies are made available for reuse under open science policies. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
notes: Since 1995, NBISC has supported gravitational biology research by distributing archived specimens. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
NBISC houses tens of thousands of biospecimens. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
SMCC (Space Microbial Culture Collection) is a new component managing microbial isolates. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

contact.inquiry: Sample requests and proposals are mediated via the NASA Life Sciences / NBISC interface. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

title: NASA Space Life Sciences Library (NSLSL)
description: The NSLSL is a centralized repository of scientific literature related to space life sciences. It includes peer-reviewed articles, technical reports, dissertations, and patents documenting biological, physiological, and medical findings from spaceflight and analog studies. The platform consolidates over 200,000 global records, is search-optimized, and supports advanced bibliometric queries. It is publicly accessible and frequently updated with research spanning microgravity, radiation, human health, biotechnology, and plant science in space environments.

title: Fire Suppression and Safety in Reduced Gravity Environments
description: This study and its accompanying simulations focused on suppressing small fires in spacecraft and extraterrestrial environments using water mist. Experiments validated fire suppression models and examined suppressant-fire interactions in various gravity (spacecraft, Moon, Mars) using ground-based tests and simulations.
objectives: Validate fire suppression simulation models for low-gravity environments
Characterize suppressant-fire interactions for engineering safer spacecraft
Provide systematic methods for fire suppression design in enclosed compartments

publications.title: Development of a Fire Suppression Simulation Tool for Various Low-Gravity Environments

impact: Enhanced understanding and modeling of fire suppression for spacecraft, Moon, Mars, and for improving fire safety practices in terrestrial applications such as aircraft, ships, and telecommunication rooms.
affiliation_address: Center for Space Resources, 1310 Maple St., Golden, CO 80401
program_element: COMBUSTION SCIENCE--Surface combustion, shs, fire safety and smoldering

title: Integrated Endurance and Resistance Exercise Countermeasures Using a Gravity Independent Training Device
description: Research focused on exercise hardware and protocols (M-MED) for maintaining astronaut fitness during long-term spaceflight. Used a gravity-independent device to test endurance and resistance training for musculoskeletal and cardiovascular health.
objectives: Validate M-MED device efficacy for cardiovascular and strength exercise
Develop time/space-efficient exercise protocols for astronaut health

publications.title: Concurrent exercise on a gravity-independent device during simulated microgravity.
Exercise responses to gravity-independent flywheel aerobic and resistance training.
Exercise training attenuates the muscle mitochondria genomic response to bedrest.

impact: Validated protocols and hardware for maintaining crew health during space missions with broader implications for efficient exercise where time/space are constrained.
affiliation_address: Dept. of Physiology & Biophysics, Irvine, CA 92697-0001
program_risks: Risk of Reduced Physical Performance Capabilities Due to Reduced Aerobic Capacity
Risk of Impaired Performance Due to Reduced Muscle Size, Strength and Endurance

title: Individual and Group Behavior of Bion-M1 Rodents
description: This project analyzed group and individual rodent behaviors during a month-long orbital mission of the Bion-M1 satellite. Used in-flight video and telemetry to study behavior, circadian patterns, and physiological adaptation in microgravity.
objectives: Examine microgravity effects on rodent general and social behavior
Integrate behavior analysis with immune, musculoskeletal, neural, and endocrine data

publications.title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: Training and selection.

impact: Pioneered group housing of male mice for long-duration flight studies, producing insights into behavioral adaptation and cross-linking behavior with health outcomes in microgravity.
